import React from 'react' import './Color.css' const Color = () => { return (
Have you ever wondered why certain objects look the way they do? Why are blueberries blue or leaves are green? Well in Chem 1410, you’re going to find the answers for all those questions and so much more. In the beginning of the course you start out discussing the beginning chapters like atomic structure and bonding, quantum-scale phenomena like intermolecular forces, and electronic structure. But as you continue throughout the course, chapter 10 discusses what exactly color is and how our eyes see colors of the visual spectrum. The information discussed in this chapter, in our opinion, is the most easy to relate to everyday life because color is seen almost everywhere!! From the branches of trees, to the color of a stop sign, or even the pigment of a bus, color is everywhere and now we know why it all appears the way it does. This fascinating information goes way beyond the chemistry course and into our everyday life. If this information is the coolest thing you’ve ever heard, then you could even consider taking this information and pursuing a career as a color chemist making pigments for company products or in laboratories experimenting with new formulas. The opportunities are endless for job opportunities and now you know why the trees are green and oceans are blue!
) } export default Color
